topic.title: Modes of Operation, Capabilities, and Limitations

body.p: A mode or sub-mode of the subsystem is defined as the initialization state of the subsystem which cannot be changed without placing the subsystem in reset. Details on the modes of operation and configuration will be added to a future issue of this document.

The overhead port has one known limitation. As noted in the functional block diagram, the device has two OHP instances. Each instance has four processing slices. The functional description describes the subsystems each slice can connect to. In the case of OHP2, there are five interfaces referred to as OHP2 I/F 0, OHP2 I/F 1. OHP2 I/F 2. OHP2 I/F 3, and OHP2 I/F 4. Use of OHP2 for system OTN FLEXO on OHP2 I/F 4 and FlexE on OHP2 I/F 3 is mutually exclusive as per the PORT_3_4_SEL mode setting. That is, overhead insertion and extraction for system OTN FLEXO interfaces and FlexE interfaces are supported but not concurrently (either system OTN FlexO or FlexE is supported). There may be use cases that utilize interfaces up to 600G OTUCn on the line side through the line OTN subsystem, client side with Nx100G FlexE through the Ethernet subsystem, and FlexO on the system side through the system OTN subsystem with bandwidth apportioned as per the application requirements. For example, with 6 x 100G client side optics, the configuration may be 2 x 100G FlexE and 4 x 100G FlexO, or 4 x 100G FlexE and 2 x 100G FlexO. In this case of mixed FlexE and FlexO client side interfaces, the OHP2 limitation would not support overhead insertion and extraction to the FlexE and FlexO clients simultaneously.
